item.description:
Pomodoro is the Italian word for tomato.  

 

In this Meetup we will explore Pomodoro Technique.  In 1992, Francesco Cirillo, an Italian university student, work out a method to make time an ally, to improve his studies.  This was in response his frustration over his low productivity. “I made a bet with myself, and it was as helpful as it was humil-iating. I asked myself, ‘Can I study—really study—for 10 minutes?' I needed objective validation—a time tutor—and I found one in a kitchen timer shaped like a pomodoro (the Italian word for “tomato”). In other words, I found my Pomodoro.”

 

What is a time box?

How can you improve your focus?

Improve your motivation?


How can you be more effective?  

 

How to stop procrastinating and GTD?

 

We'll explore the Pomodoro rules, such as:

The Pomodoro Is Indivisible.

If a Pomodoro Begins, It Has to Ring

 

Some of the material for our discussion is drawn from the book: Pomodoro Technique Illustrated The Easy Way to Do More in Less Time, by Staffan Nöteberg.
item.how_to_find_us: Look for us at the large table all the way in back...
item.name: Pomodoro Technique ...tick ...tick ...tick
